Title: the hawking excitation

Scene: The cafeteria. Sheldon enters in the French maid costume.
Howard: So, I got the craziest e-mail this morning.
Believe me, I know. The e-mail I got was from the office of Stephen Hawking.
He’s coming to the university for a couple weeks to lecture, and he’s looking for an engineer to help maintain the equipment on his wheelchair.
I was actually thinking about bringing him along when I go over there so he can meet the great man.
Hm, it’s no big deal.
Sheldon, I have a working understanding of physics.
Yep.
Not on your life.
I told you, no.
No, you said, would it help if I said I’m sorry?
Sheldon, you’re a condescending jerk. Why on earth would I want to do something nice for you?
Jews don’t have heaven.
Have you met my mother? I live in Jewish hell.
Oh, you can’t be serious.
Hang on. Are you saying the rest of us are dogs?
Get out of my lab.
Get out.
Out!
It was great. We talked about movies.
I showed him some card tricks.
He even let me read a couple pages from his new book.
Something got you down there, bunky?
You’re kidding.
You don’t seem to be understanding the English word no. Maybe a different language will help. Russian, nyet. Chinese, bu. Japanese, iie. Klingon, qo. Binary coded Ascii, 0110111001101111.
No!
Let me try gansta, hells no.
That’s an interesting idea. Why don’t you give me a minute to talk it over with my friends?
You walk away.
I do.
Yeah, I know, I’m just trying to figure out how much I want to punish him.
Sheldon, come on back.
I’ll give your paper to Professor Hawking.
But in exchange, I’d like you to do a few things for me.
Are you familiar with the 12 labours of Hercules?
You should be so lucky.
Well, I thought I’d start you off by polishing my belt buckles.
That’s nice.

Funny thing is, I only have one belt. Anyway, I’ll let you get started. Oh, by the way, the little marks, uh, that look like water spots, I tend to stand too close to the urinal, so what you’re seeing there is splash back.
Here is a black light to check them. And for your own peace of mind, you might not want to shine that around the rest of the room.
Sheldon, these look great. They’re like magnificent little crowns to hang over my magnificent little jewels. How’d you get them so shiny?
Way to go the extra mile. Your Mee-Maw would be proud.

Oh, my dear boy, no. Okay. Next, this is a sexy French maid costume I bought for Bernadette. I thought it might spice things up and get her to dust my room at the same time, but I was wrong and really wrong.
No, no, no, mon petit cherie.
What’s the matter?
It’s not her fault. She’s getting hormone replacement therapy. Makes her crazy horny. Check this out, I got Sheldon to wear the French maid’s costume.
Hey, I gave you first crack at it.
He’s mean to me all the time. You’ve heard him tease me about not having a doctorate.
Oh, come on, the man torments me. I’m just letting him have a little taste of his own medicine.
Fine, I’ll just make him do a couple more things, then I’ll stop.
Oh, guys, I just remembered. I got you some Hawking souvenirs.
Gears and springs from his wheelchair. Pretty cool, huh?
Yeah, I made an adjustment on the motor drive and when I was putting it back together I could not for the life of me figure out where they went.
I should have sent you to the custom car cover place in Altadena. They have her pattern on file.
I don’t know.
All right, Sheldon, there’s only one thing left I want you to do. Don’t worry, it’s an easy one.
Give me a compliment.
No, about my job. I want you to tell me I’m good at what I do.
Well, then why are you always ripping on me?
Thank you, Sheldon.
Sorry, I can’t.
I gave it to him three days ago. He was really impressed. He wants to meet you.
Raj: I don’t mean to burst your bubble, dude, but those penile enlargement pills do not work.
Oh, boy, Sheldon’s going to freak out.
That’s really nice of you, Howard.
That’s incredible. Oh, here, break out the math.
Are you still going to tell him about you-know-who?

Three times. He begged the Fox network not to cancel Firefly. He begged the TNT network to cancel Babylon 5. And when he got food poisoning at the Rose Bowl Parade, he begged a deity he doesn’t believe in to end his life quickly.
You can make him do anything you want.
Bring him to his bony knees.
I thought he might be a little more excited.
Leonard: That’s amazing. You’ll be like his pit crew. A word of caution, I would not do your Stephen Hawking impression in front of him.
Boy, a restraining order from Stephen Hawking. It’ll look so nice next to the ones he’s already got from Leonard Nimoy, Carl Sagan and Stan Lee.
Like it was ten hours ago. What about it?
So, come on, how was the first day with Hawking?
Raj, you’re our group historian. Has Sheldon ever begged before?
You do realize you own his ass right now.
It’s nicer than anything he’s ever said to me. I’d take it and run.
Give it a second. (Sound of Sheldon shrieking in joy in his bedroom)
Howard (in Stephen Hawking voice): You’re right. I suppose that could be considered offensive.
Sheldon: Leonard, do you recall when I said that I was going to revolutionize humanity’s understanding of the Higgs boson particle, and you said, Sheldon, it’s two a.m., get out of my bedroom?
Well, I believe I’ve done it. And I’m only saying believe to sound modest, because, sweet Sam Houston, I did it.
Oh, okay, let me see this. All right, so this particle here is the boson moving forward in time. Now, I was thinking… Howard, you go ahead and eat. This isn’t going to make any sense to you.
Yeah, good for you, and don’t stop working on it.
Please, please, please let me meet Hawking.
But I said I’m sorry.
And you never answered me. So who owes whom an apology now?
Um, to go to Jewish heaven?
Then to avoid Jewish hell?
Howard, please. This is Stephen Hawking. Perhaps my only intellectual equal.
Try to put yourself in my place. Imagine you’re the sole human being living on a planet populated with nothing but dogs. And then it turns out there’s another human being.
Yeah, okay, I can see you’re going to take this the wrong way. Let me try again. Imagine you’re the sole human being living on a planet populated with nothing but chimps.
Oh, now they’re so much smarter than dogs. Have you seen them on those little bicycles?
How about dolphins?
Oh!
Oh!
Oh!
Howard, please, I’m begging you.
Do you understand how important Hawking is to me? When I was six years old, I dressed up as him for Halloween.

No, sir, no, I took my dad’s desk chair, attached a Speak & Spell to it and made my sister push me up and down the block to trick or treat. Granted most people thought I was R2-D2, but still, I got a lot of candy.
It’s actually 01100111.
I’m not asking for me, I’m asking for Hawking.
Okay, look, how about this? Just give him my paper on the Higgs boson. If he sees the incredible breakthrough I’ve made, he’ll reach out to me.
He will, he’s really smart.
How do I do that?
Walking away.
Hey, fellas, I’m thinking about making some freshly brewed iced tea if anyone would like some.
I wasn’t talking to you.
Yes, yes. What did you decide?
Great, thank you. Oh, that’s terrific.
What kinds of things?
Of course.
All right. What would you like me to do first?

Oh. By all means. When I was a boy, I would polish my Mee-Maw’s silver. And she would entertain me with stories about growing up in Oklahoma. Interesting woman. You know, she once killed a prairie dog with a gravy boat.
That’s a lot of belt buckles.
You make sissy on your belt buckles? Mee-Maw’s forks never had that.
Oh, I-I buffed them with Turtle Wax. The man down at Pep Boys says from now on, the urine should just bead up and roll right off.
My Mee-Maw must never know of this. Now will you give Professor Hawking my paper?
And you want me to return it for you?
What are you all staring at? Didn’t you ever see a man try to get a meeting with Stephen Hawking before?
Hello.
This is not my laundry.
Those are Howard’s.
Because if I don’t, he won’t give my paper to Stephen Hawking. He’s a famous physicist.
That’s close enough.
Because he’s punishing me for being a, quote, condescending jerk. You don’t think I’m condescending, do you?
Oh, I’m sorry, condescending means…
Au contraire. When I correct people I am raising them up. You should know, I do it for you more than anyone.
Or Don Quixote is a book about a donkey named Hotay.
Well, I can’t help it. That’s an involuntary twinkle.
I want you to tell me that Howard is being mean to me for no reason.
I knew it.
What is it now, Mrs. Wolowitz?
What do you want me to do?
Oh, no, you know, I’m not really the holding kind of… Oh!
I did it. Had to go to three clothing stores, but we finally found a dress that could envelop your mother.
Humorous. Now will you please present my paper to Professor Hawking?
Oh, for heaven’s sake. I did your laundry, I pee-pee-proofed your belt buckles, I, I even sprained my wrist helping your mother lift her bosom.
Okay.
Fine. You have very tiny hands.
You’re obviously good at what you do.
Oh, I understand the confusion. I have never said that you are not good at what you do. It’s just that what you do is not worth doing.
Now will you give my paper to Hawking?
What, why not?
All right, then. Thank you, Howard. Please let Professor Hawking know that I’m available at his earliest convenience.
Professor Hawking, it’s an honour and a privilege to meet you, sir.
I want to thank you for taking time to see me.
I know.
Thank you. It just, it came to me one morning in the shower.
What do you mean wrong?
No, no, th-th-th-that can’t be right. I-I don’t make arithmetic mistakes.
Oh, no, no, no, of course not. It’s just, I was thinking… Oh, gosh, golly, I made a boo-boo, and I gave it to Stephen Hawking.
Penny: It’s not Saturday night. Why are you doing your laundry?
Wow, are these Amy’s? Kind of trashy, good for her.
Ugh. Why are you washing Howard’s man panties?
Yeah, yeah, I know, he’s the wheelchair dude who invented time.
I don’t understand, why doesn’t Howard just introduce you to the guy?
I know what it means. And yes, you love correcting people and putting them down.
Come on, you do it to feel superior. I see that twinkle in your eye when someone says who instead of whom or thinks the moon is a planet.
See, there it is, there’s that twinkle.
What do you want me to tell you, Sheldon?
Fine, Howard is being mean to you for no reason.
Bernadette: Every time I spend the night, your mom slaps me on the behind and says, go get ‘im.
Why are you doing that? You’re being mean to him.
If you don’t want to get teased about that, get a doctorate. I have one, they’re great.
It’s not the same thing. Sheldon doesn’t know when he’s being mean because the part of his brain that should know is getting a wedgie from the rest of his brain.
No, you have to stop now.
Oh, damn. I’m sorry, I can’t make it, but Sheldon’s going to go with you! And that’s the last thing you do to him.
Mrs Wolowitz (off): Bernadette, I want to remind you, you promised to take me dress shopping tomorrow!
It’s this dress. When I put my front in, my back pops out. When I put my back in, my front pops out. It’s like trying to keep two dogs in a bathtub!
We’re gonna have to work as a team. Get in here, grab a handful, and start stuffing.
It’s easy, just pretend you’re putting away a sleeping bag.
You’re right, who am I kidding? You should have seen me when I was young, Sheldon. The fellas used to line up and bring me boxes of candy. Why did I eat it all? Would you hold me?
Sheldon (off): I’m not sure how to do this.
Sleeping bags don’t usually sweat this much, but okay.
Oh, if we squeeze you any tighter, you may turn into a diamond.
Hawking: My pleasure. I enjoyed reading your paper very much. You clearly have a brilliant mind.
Your thesis that the Higgs boson is a black hole accelerating backwards through time is fascinating.
That’s nice. Too bad it’s wrong.
You made an arithmetic mistake on page two. It was quite the boner.

Um, to go to Jewish heaven?

Hang on. Are you saying the rest of us are dogs?

Oh, now they’re so much smarter than dogs. Have you seen them on those little bicycles?
So, come on, how was the first day with Hawking?

Do you understand how important Hawking is to me? When I was six years old, I dressed up as him for Halloween.

I’m not asking for me, I’m asking for Hawking.

That’s an interesting idea. Why don’t you give me a minute to talk it over with my friends?
You do realize you own his ass right now.
You can make him do anything you want.
Yeah, I know, I’m just trying to figure out how much I want to punish him.
Hey, fellas, I’m thinking about making some freshly brewed iced tea if anyone would like some.
Bring him to his bony knees.
Yes, yes. What did you decide?
I’ll give your paper to Professor Hawking.
Great, thank you. Oh, that’s terrific.
But in exchange, I’d like you to do a few things for me.
Are you familiar with the 12 labours of Hercules?
All right. What would you like me to do first?
Well, I thought I’d start you off by polishing my belt buckles.

Oh. By all means. When I was a boy, I would polish my Mee-Maw’s silver. And she would entertain me with stories about growing up in Oklahoma. Interesting woman. You know, she once killed a prairie dog with a gravy boat.
That’s a lot of belt buckles.

Funny thing is, I only have one belt. Anyway, I’ll let you get started. Oh, by the way, the little marks, uh, that look like water spots, I tend to stand too close to the urinal, so what you’re seeing there is splash back.
You make sissy on your belt buckles? Mee-Maw’s forks never had that.

Sheldon, these look great. They’re like magnificent little crowns to hang over my magnificent little jewels. How’d you get them so shiny?
Oh, I-I buffed them with Turtle Wax. The man down at Pep Boys says from now on, the urine should just bead up and roll right off.
Way to go the extra mile. Your Mee-Maw would be proud.
My Mee-Maw must never know of this. Now will you give Professor Hawking my paper?

Oh, my dear boy, no. Okay. Next, this is a sexy French maid costume I bought for Bernadette. I thought it might spice things up and get her to dust my room at the same time, but I was wrong and really wrong.
And you want me to return it for you?
No, no, no, mon petit cherie.
The cafeteria. Sheldon enters in the French maid costume.
What are you all staring at? Didn’t you ever see a man try to get a meeting with Stephen Hawking before?
It’s not Saturday night. Why are you doing your laundry?
Wow, are these Amy’s? Kind of trashy, good for her.
Ugh. Why are you washing Howard’s man panties?
Because if I don’t, he won’t give my paper to Stephen Hawking. He’s a famous physicist.
Yeah, yeah, I know, he’s the wheelchair dude who invented time.
I don’t understand, why doesn’t Howard just introduce you to the guy?
Because he’s punishing me for being a, quote, condescending jerk. You don’t think I’m condescending, do you?
I know what it means. And yes, you love correcting people and putting them down.
Au contraire. When I correct people I am raising them up. You should know, I do it for you more than anyone.
Come on, you do it to feel superior. I see that twinkle in your eye when someone says who instead of whom or thinks the moon is a planet.
Or Don Quixote is a book about a donkey named Hotay.
See, there it is, there’s that twinkle.
Well, I can’t help it. That’s an involuntary twinkle.
What do you want me to tell you, Sheldon?
I want you to tell me that Howard is being mean to me for no reason.
Fine, Howard is being mean to you for no reason.
Every time I spend the night, your mom slaps me on the behind and says, go get ‘im.
It’s not her fault. She’s getting hormone replacement therapy. Makes her crazy horny. Check this out, I got Sheldon to wear the French maid’s costume.
Hey, I gave you first crack at it.
Why are you doing that? You’re being mean to him.
He’s mean to me all the time. You’ve heard him tease me about not having a doctorate.
If you don’t want to get teased about that, get a doctorate. I have one, they’re great.
Oh, come on, the man torments me. I’m just letting him have a little taste of his own medicine.
It’s not the same thing. Sheldon doesn’t know when he’s being mean because the part of his brain that should know is getting a wedgie from the rest of his brain.
Fine, I’ll just make him do a couple more things, then I’ll stop.
No, you have to stop now.
Bernadette, I want to remind you, you promised to take me dress shopping tomorrow!
Oh, damn. I’m sorry, I can’t make it, but Sheldon’s going to go with you! And that’s the last thing you do to him.
What is it now, Mrs. Wolowitz?
It’s this dress. When I put my front in, my back pops out. When I put my back in, my front pops out. It’s like trying to keep two dogs in a bathtub!
What do you want me to do?
We’re gonna have to work as a team. Get in here, grab a handful, and start stuffing.
I’m not sure how to do this.
It’s easy, just pretend you’re putting away a sleeping bag.
Sleeping bags don’t usually sweat this much, but okay.
Oh, if we squeeze you any tighter, you may turn into a diamond.
You’re right, who am I kidding? You should have seen me when I was young, Sheldon. The fellas used to line up and bring me boxes of candy. Why did I eat it all? Would you hold me?
Oh, no, you know, I’m not really the holding kind of… Oh!
Oh, guys, I just remembered. I got you some Hawking souvenirs.
Gears and springs from his wheelchair. Pretty cool, huh?
Yeah, I made an adjustment on the motor drive and when I was putting it back together I could not for the life of me figure out where they went.
I did it. Had to go to three clothing stores, but we finally found a dress that could envelop your mother.
I should have sent you to the custom car cover place in Altadena. They have her pattern on file.
Humorous. Now will you please present my paper to Professor Hawking?
Oh, for heaven’s sake. I did your laundry, I pee-pee-proofed your belt buckles, I, I even sprained my wrist helping your mother lift her bosom.
All right, Sheldon, there’s only one thing left I want you to do. Don’t worry, it’s an easy one.
Fine. You have very tiny hands.
No, about my job. I want you to tell me I’m good at what I do.
You’re obviously good at what you do.
Well, then why are you always ripping on me?
Oh, I understand the confusion. I have never said that you are not good at what you do. It’s just that what you do is not worth doing.
It’s nicer than anything he’s ever said to me. I’d take it and run.
Now will you give my paper to Hawking?
I gave it to him three days ago. He was really impressed. He wants to meet you.
All right, then. Thank you, Howard. Please let Professor Hawking know that I’m available at his earliest convenience.
I thought he might be a little more excited.
Give it a second. (Sound of Sheldon shrieking in joy in his bedroom)
Professor Hawking, it’s an honour and a privilege to meet you, sir.
I want to thank you for taking time to see me.
My pleasure. I enjoyed reading your paper very much. You clearly have a brilliant mind.
Your thesis that the Higgs boson is a black hole accelerating backwards through time is fascinating.
Thank you. It just, it came to me one morning in the shower.
That’s nice. Too bad it’s wrong.
You made an arithmetic mistake on page two. It was quite the boner.
No, no, th-th-th-that can’t be right. I-I don’t make arithmetic mistakes.
Oh, no, no, no, of course not. It’s just, I was thinking… Oh, gosh, golly, I made a boo-boo, and I gave it to Stephen Hawking.
